# Contracts Management System# Contracts

A modern contract management system built with Angular 18+, Module Federation, and AWS Cognito authentication.<a alt="Nx logo" href="https://nx.dev" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer"><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nrwl/nx/master/images/nx-logo.png" width="45"></a>

This project uses **Nx Workspace** with **Module Federation** architecture:## Integrate with editors

- **Host App**: Main application shell with authentication and routingEnhance your Nx experience by installing [Nx Console](https://nx.dev/nx-console) for your favorite editor. Nx Console

- **ERP Microfrontend**: Contract management module loaded dynamicallyprovides an interactive UI to view your projects, run tasks, generate code, and more! Available for VSCode, IntelliJ and

- **Design System Library**: Shared UI components (Table, Input, Card, Layout, etc.)comes with a LSP for Vim users.

## ğŸ¨ Tech Stack## Nx plugins and code generators

- **Angular 18+**: Standalone components with new control flow syntaxAdd Nx plugins to leverage their code generators and automated, inferred tasks.

- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework with custom Genius Soft brand colors

- **AWS Amplify**: Authentication with Cognito```

- **NgRx**: State management for user and UI state# Add plugin

- **Module Federation**: Micro frontend architecturenpx nx add @nx/react

- **Lucide Icons**: Modern icon library

- **JSON Server**: Mock API for development# Use code generator

npx nx generate @nx/react:app demo

# Run development server

### Installation

Run `npx nx list` to get a list of available plugins and whether they have generators. Then run `npx nx list <plugin-name>` to see what generators are available.

1. Clone the repository:

```bashLearn more about [code generators](https://nx.dev/features/generate-code) and [inferred tasks](https://nx.dev/concepts/inferred-tasks) in the docs.

git clone https://github.com/jaralabs/contracts.git

cd contracts## Running tasks

````

To execute tasks with Nx use the following syntax:

2. Install dependencies:

`bash`

npm installnpx nx <target> <project> <...options>

````



3. Configure environment variables:You can also run multiple targets:

```bash

cp .env.example .env```

```npx nx run-many -t <target1> <target2>

```

Edit `.env` with your AWS Cognito credentials:

```env..or add `-p` to filter specific projects

AWS_REGION=us-east-1

AWS_USER_POOL_ID=your-user-pool-id```

AWS_USER_POOL_CLIENT_ID=your-client-idnpx nx run-many -t <target1> <target2> -p <proj1> <proj2>

AWS_IDENTITY_POOL_ID=your-identity-pool-id```

```

Targets can be defined in the `package.json` or `projects.json`. Learn more [in the docs](https://nx.dev/features/run-tasks).

4. Start the development servers:

```bash## Set up CI!

# Start JSON Server (mock API)

npm run serverNx comes with local caching already built-in (check your `nx.json`). On CI you might want to go a step further.



# In another terminal, start Host app- [Set up remote caching](https://nx.dev/features/share-your-cache)

npx nx serve host- [Set up task distribution across multiple machines](https://nx.dev/nx-cloud/features/distribute-task-execution)

- [Learn more how to setup CI](https://nx.dev/recipes/ci)

# In another terminal, start ERP microfrontend

npx nx serve erp## Explore the project graph

```

Run `npx nx graph` to show the graph of the workspace.

5. Open your browser:It will show tasks that you can run with Nx.

- Host: http://localhost:4200

- ERP: http://localhost:4200/erp- [Learn more about Exploring the Project Graph](https://nx.dev/core-features/explore-graph)



## ğŸ¨ Design System## Connect with us!



### Brand Colors- [Join the community](https://nx.dev/community)

- [Subscribe to the Nx Youtube Channel](https://www.youtube.com/@nxdevtools)

- **Primary Orange**: `#F57C00` (Genius Soft corporate color)- [Follow us on Twitter](https://twitter.com/nxdevtools)

- **Primary Scale**: 50-900 (based on orange)
- **Secondary Scale**: Gray colors for text and backgrounds

### Components

- `HeaderComponent`: Application header with logo and user badge
- `LayoutComponent`: Main layout with collapsible sidebar
- `TableComponent`: Dynamic table with sorting, pagination, and selection
- `InputComponent`: Form input with ControlValueAccessor
- `CardComponent`: Reusable card component
- `LabelComponent`: Form label component

## ğŸ” Authentication

The application uses **AWS Cognito** for authentication:

- Email/password login
- Password change flow
- Auth guards protecting routes
- Centralized auth service
- NgRx store for user state

### Test Users

Configure test users in your AWS Cognito User Pool.

## ğŸ§ª Testing

```bash
# Run all tests
npx nx run-many -t test

# Run tests for specific project
npx nx test host
npx nx test erp
npx nx test design-system

# Run tests with coverage
npx nx test host --coverage
```

## ğŸ—ï¸ Building

```bash
# Build for production
npx nx run-many -t build

# Build specific app
npx nx build host --configuration=production
npx nx build erp --configuration=production
```

## ğŸ“ Development Guidelines

### Commit Messages

Follow [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/):

- `feat:` New features
- `fix:` Bug fixes
- `refactor:` Code refactoring
- `docs:` Documentation changes
- `style:` Code style changes
- `test:` Test additions or changes
- `chore:` Build process or auxiliary tool changes

Example:
```bash
git commit -m "feat: add contract filtering functionality"
```

### Code Style

- Use Angular standalone components
- Use new control flow syntax (`@if`, `@for`)
- Use Tailwind utility classes instead of SCSS
- Follow single responsibility principle
- Write meaningful component and variable names

## ğŸ¯ Available Scripts

- `npx nx serve host` - Start host application
- `npx nx serve erp` - Start ERP microfrontend
- `npm run server` - Start JSON Server (port 3000)
- `npx nx build host` - Build host application
- `npx nx test host` - Run tests
- `npx nx lint host` - Run ESLint

## ğŸ¤ Contributing

1. Create a feature branch: `git checkout -b feat/my-feature`
2. Make your changes
3. Run tests: `npx nx test`
4. Commit using conventional commits
5. Push and create a Pull Request
